g.text: Many aspects of the observed mean state of the atmosphere
consistent with our simulated response to Arctic sea-ice changes.
ERA-Interim estimates of the precipitation, geopotential, and
OLR anomalies between 2012 and 2015 (relative to the period
2010) are shown in Supplementary Fig. 7. Similar to our
simulations, ERA-Interim exhibits a geopotential ridge in the
c and a precipitation decrease over California (Sup-
plementary Fig. 7a, b). In the tropics, precipitation decreases
across the central and eastern tropical Paci
northward of this region and in the west tropical Paci
plementary Fig. 7a). Another commonality is the behavior of OLR
changes across the central tropical Paci
Supplementary Fig. 7c). The magnitudes of the observed 3-year
mean anomalies during the recent California drought (Supple-
mentary Fig. 7a) are much larger than the magnitudes of the 20-
year mean response to sea-ice changes shown in Fig. 2a. This is
expected given that the longer 20-year period contains both dry
and wet years. As seen from Supplementary Fig. 8a, low Arctic
sea-ice increases the likelihood of drier California, but does not
result in drier conditions over California every single year. On
average, when considering the 20-year mean, there is a 10
Fig. 8b) indicates that the magnitude of the simulated precipita-
tion response is comparable to the magnitude of changes in ERA-
Interim during the most recent drought.
This consistency does not, however, constitute compelling
Arctic sea-ice changes. Rather, it illustrates that some of the
atmospheric features of the droughts driven by Arctic sea-ice loss
may resemble those of the most recent California drought. The
cation of dry conditions over California since late 2012
may have also been affected by several other factors not discussed
in this study, such as the appearance of a large warm SST
anomaly off the west coast of North America
appears to be a consequence rather than a cause of the altered
tant factor may be the 2014 phase shift of the Paci
Oscillation from negative to positive. However, this shift would be
expected to alleviate drought conditions over California
. Finally, we note that other hemispherically
include asymmetric forcing by anthropogenic aerosols, volcanic
eruptions, and solar irradiance variations. All of these forcings
can alter the inter-hemispheric temperature gradient
causing shifts in the location of tropical convection and initiating
It is of interest to consider whether paleoclimatic evidence
provides support for our model-inferred two-step teleconnection
(Fig. 4). We focus on past periods with pronounced excursions in
Arctic temperatures and sea-ice cover. The
step teleconnection is well documented in both paleoclimate
simulations and paleoclimate records of the last glacial period
Abrupt high-latitude temperature increase during the last inter-
are manifest in the tropics through a northward shift in
Schematics of the two-step teleconnection. In step 1 (equatorward propagation), Arctic sea-ice loss induced high-latitude changes propagate into
tropics, triggering tropical circulation and convection response. Decreased convection and decreased upper-level divergence in the tropical Paci
drive a northward-propagating Rossby wavetrain with anticyclonic
ow forming in the North Paci
c. This ridge is responsible for steering the wet tropical
